abstract.shortdesc: This page displays the alarms for all services and appliances. By default, alarms are sorted by most recent and in a table format.

section.title: Create Alarm Definition
section.p:
Opens the Create Alarm Definition Screen. Here you can define the following properties of a new alarm:
Details Name, Description
Notifications and Severity Severity, Notification Methods
Alarm Expression Function, Metric, Relational Operator, Value, Dimension

section.title: Search and Sort
section.p: The search bar allows you to filter the alarms you want to view. Type and Status are examples of alarm criteria that can be specified. Additionally, you can filter by typing in text similar to searching by keywords.
The checkbox allows you to select (or deselect) a group of alarms and apply a single condition on the selected alarms.
You can display the alarms by grid, list or table views by selecting the corresponding icons next to the Sort By control.
The Sort By control contains a drop-down list of ways by which you can sort the alarms. Alternatively, you can also sort using the column headers in the table.

ul.li: Sort by Dimension displays the alarms by device, hostname and service which they belong to.
Sort by Alarm ID displays the alarms UUID.
Sort by State displays the alarms by reported status of OK, Warning, Error, and Unknown
Sort by Service displays the name of the service that triggers the alarm.

section.title: Alarm Table
section.p: Each row has a checkbox to allow you to select multiple alarms and set the same condition on them.
The State column displays a graphical indicator that shows the state of each alarm:

ul.li: Green square (or green indicator): OK. Good operating state.
Yellow diamond (or yellow indicator): Warning. Low severity, not requiring immediate action.
Red ball (or red indicator): Alarm. Varying severity levels and must be addressed.

section.p: The Alarm column identifies the alarm by the name it was given when it was originally created.
The Last Check column displays the date and time the most recent occurrence of the alarm.
The Dimension column describes the components to check in order to clear the alarm.
The last column, depicted by three dots, reveals an Actions menu that allows you to choose:

ul.li: View Details, which opens a separate window that shows all the information from the table view and the alarm history. You also have the ability to add a comment to the alarm. You cannot edit the alarm definition from this screen. You can click View Alarm Definition to open the Edit Alarm Definitino page.
View Alarm Definition, which opens a separate window that allows you to directly edit the alarm details.
Suggested Resolutions, which opens a separate window displaying the HPE Helion OpenStack Alarm Resolution Procedures documentation.
Delete, which opens a separate window asking you to Confirm or Cancel the deletion. You are shown how many alarms will be deleted and warns you that this action cannot be undone.
